Award.AwardTitle: BPC-AE: The STARS Alliance: A Southeastern Partnership for Broadening Participation in Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of North Carolina, Charlotte proposes to extend the size, scope and impact of the existing BPC STARS Alliance. STARS is a cohesive system of regional partnerships that aims to broaden participation in computing. It collaboratively and systematically implements, disseminates, and institutionalizes effective practices for increasing the number of women, under-represented minorities, and persons with disabilities in the computing disciplines. This proposed Extension focuses on the recruitment, bridging, and retention of under-represented student populations, the advancement of junior faculty, and the sustainability and dissemination of the STARS Southeastern Constellation as a replicable network of regional partnerships, that can be implemented in other geographic regions. It includes new activities aimed at K-6. The Extension will grow the Alliance to include at least 20 academic institutions and 80 regional partners, and it will double student participation in the STARS Student Leadership Corps (SLC), including community colleges, as well as middle and high school students, teachers and guidance counselors. Finally, it will extend the existing program evaluation to explore STARS impact on the computing culture at member institutions.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The STARS Alliance is a community that serves as a national resource for broadening participation in computing (BPC) through student- led regional engagement, in the STARS Computing Corps. The Corps has demonstrated its efficacy as a model for student engagement in technical excellence, leadership, community, service and civic engagement, and as a framework for integrating BPC practices into the core mission of computing departments. 

Since 2006, 49 colleges and universities have implemented the  Corps with 1,134 Corps students who have reached over 46,000 K-14 students.  The Alliance has hosted 7 STARS Celebrations with 1,710 students, faculty and partners participating in over 318 workshops in technical excellence, leadership, community & civic engagement practices that broaden participation in computing. The STARS Online community was launched in 2011 and serves as a vital communication tool between individuals, as well as between & across school groups. STARS Online has  697 individual participants, 41 School Groups, and 20 Affinity Groups who share ideas about BPC implemenation in their communities. STARS has made significant national contributions by disseminating a collection of STARS practices to the BPC Portal; 52 resources, such as best practices, 'how to's', tools and outcomes research, have been published to the STARS Digital Library through the BPC Portal to date. In addition,  the STARS Alliance has produced 20 journal articles, 54 conference papers, and 18 conference posters disseminating knowledge about our practices.

 

Individual Impact

  •  The STARS Alliance has demonstrated increases in grade point average, computing professional identity, confidence in computing abilities, belief in the social relevance of computing, and commitment to obtaining a computing degree among Corps students*.
  • The Corps is reaching underreprented populations in computing. Half of the 1,134 Corps students have been female, and nearly half (41%) have been African Americans and 10% Hispanic.

Organizational Capacity Development

  • 25 STARS Alliance institutions have formed mentoring programs and have mentored 517 students.
  • 18 STARS Alliance institutions have established permanent BPC practices through academic credit bearing courses for Corps activities and student clubs.

National Resource for Broadening Participation in Computing

  • The STARS Alliance has held 7 Celebration conferences providing over 318 training and professional development workshops to students, faculty and community partners.
  • STAR Online connects over 700 students, faculty and community partners via 20 Affinity Groups and 41 school groups who share information, resources and ideas.
  • STARS has supplied 52 resources to the national online portal, the BPC Digital Library.

*Dahlberg, T., Barnes, T., Buch, K. & Rorrer, A. (2011). The STARS Alliance: Viable strategies for broadening participation in computing. Transactions on Computer Education, Special Issue on Broadening Participation, 11 (3),18.

 

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily  reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The STARS Alliance is a community that serves as a national resource for broadening participation in computing (BPC) through student- led regional engagement, in the STARS Computing Corps. The Corps has demonstrated its efficacy as a model for student engagement in technical excellence, leadership, community, service and civic engagement, and as a framework for integrating BPC practices into the core mission of computing departments. Since 2006, 49 colleges and universities have implemented the Corps with 1,134 Corps students who have reached over 46,000 K-14 students. The Alliance has hosted 7 STARS Celebrations with 1,710 students, faculty and partners participating in over 318 workshops in technical excellence, leadership, community & civic engagement practices that broaden participation in computing. The STARS Online community was launched in 2011 and serves as a vital communication tool between individuals, as well as between & across school groups. STARS Online has 697 individual participants, 41 School Groups, and 20 Affinity Groups who share ideas about BPC implemenation in their communities. STARS has made significant national contributions by disseminating a collection of STARS practices to the BPC Portal; 52 resources, such as best practices, 'how to's', tools and outcomes research, have been published to the STARS Digital Library through the BPC Portal to date. In addition, the STARS Alliance has produced 20 journal articles, 54 conference papers, and 18 conference posters disseminating knowledge about our practices. Individual Impact The STARS Alliance has demonstrated increases in grade point average, computing professional identity, confidence in computing abilities, belief in the social relevance of computing, and commitment to obtaining a computing degree among Corps students*. The Corps is reaching underreprented populations in computing. Half of the 1,134 Corps students have been female, and nearly half (41%) have been African Americans and 10% Hispanic. Organizational Capacity Development 25 STARS Alliance institutions have formed mentoring programs and have mentored 517 students. 18 STARS Alliance institutions have established permanent BPC practices through academic credit bearing courses for Corps activities and student clubs. National Resource for Broadening Participation in Computing The STARS Alliance has held 7 Celebration conferences providing over 318 training and professional development workshops to students, faculty and community partners. STAR Online connects over 700 students, faculty and community partners via 20 Affinity Groups and 41 school groups who share information, resources and ideas. STARS has supplied 52 resources to the national online portal, the BPC Digital Library. *Dahlberg, T., Barnes, T., Buch, K. & Rorrer, A. (2011). The STARS Alliance: Viable strategies for broadening participation in computing. Transactions on Computer Education, Special Issue on Broadening Participation, 11 (3),18.
